50-65.description: Winston is approached by Mrs. Parsons who asks for his help with a blocked kitchen sink. They discuss the issue and proceed to her apartment, which is cluttered and smells of cabbage and sweat.
50-65.dialog_summary: Mrs. Parsons asks Winston to help with the blocked sink. She mentions her husband Tom would have fixed it if he were home.
text_phrases: left the diary open on the table
dirty dishes and dog-eared exercise books
scarlet banners of the Youth League and the Spies

66-81.description: Winston is surrounded by Mrs. Parsons's children who are aggressively calling him a traitor and expressing a desire to physically attack him.
66-81.dialog_summary: Mrs. Parsons explains the children's noisy behavior by their disappointment at not being able to see a hanging.
text_phrases: dust in the creases of her face

66-81.description: Winston listens to a military voice from the telescreen announcing a victory on the Malabar front and the subsequent reduction of the chocolate ration.
66-81.dialog_summary: The telescreen announces a victory and a reduction in the chocolate ration.
text_phrases: sat down at the table again
music from the telescreen had stopped
clipped military voice was reading out

82-97.description: Winston stands by the window, reflecting on the oppressive doctrines of the Party, as he observes the torn poster outside and the Ministry of Truth.
text_phrases: Winston walked over to the window
keeping his back to the telescreen
the white face of the Ministry of Truth

82-97.description: Winston contemplates his existence and the futility of his actions against the Party, writes in his diary, and takes precautions to hide his activities.
text_phrases: put the diary away in the drawer
picked up an identifiable grain of whitish dust

82-97.description: Winston dreams of his mother and sister, recalling their disappearance during the purges, and visualizes them in a sinking ship scenario, symbolizing their sacrifice for his survival.
text_phrases: his mother was sitting in some place deep down beneath him
the saloon of a sinking ship
they were sinking down, down into the green waters

98-106.scene_title: Winston's Dream of His Mother and Sister
98-106.description: Winston experiences a vivid dream where he recalls the sacrifice of his mother and sister, which evokes deep emotions contrasting with the current state of society where such feelings are no longer possible.
text_phrases: large eyes of his mother and his sister
looking up at him through the green water

98-106.description: Winston finds himself in a recurring dream landscape known as the Golden Country, featuring a pastoral setting with natural elements and a mysterious girl.
text_phrases: slanting rays of the sun gilded the ground
boughs of the elm trees were swaying

98-106.description: Winston wakes up to the harsh sound of the telescreen and participates in the mandatory morning exercise routine, reflecting on his past and the stark differences in society.
98-106.dialog_summary: The instructor on the telescreen directs the Physical Jerks routine, encouraging participants to put more effort into the exercises.
text_phrases: telescreen was giving forth an ear-splitting whistle
naked, for a member of the Outer Party
dingy singlet and a pair of shorts
youngish woman, scrawny but muscular, dressed in tunic and gym shoes

107-116.description: Winston, along with his parents, finds a spot on the stone-flagged floor of a crowded shelter where people are sitting on metal bunks and the floor. An old man nearby, reeking of gin and visibly distressed, repeatedly expresses regret about misplaced trust.
107-116.dialog_summary: The old man repeatedly laments trusting 'them', indicating a betrayal or a grave mistake, though it's unclear who 'they' are.
text_phrases: people sitting all over the stone-flagged floor

107-116.description: Winston participates in a physical exercise session led by an instructress, performing stretches and touching his toes, which he finds painful and loathsome.
107-116.dialog_summary: The instructress commands the group to perform exercises, encouraging them to stretch and touch their toes.
text_phrases: with hands on hips, they were gyrating their bodies from the waist
let's see which of us can touch our toes

117-130.description: Winston is being monitored and instructed on physical exercises by an instructress through the telescreen. He struggles but eventually manages to perform the exercises as demonstrated.
117-130.dialog_summary: The instructress from the telescreen aggressively guides Winston and others to perform physical exercises, emphasizing the importance of fitness.

117-130.description: Winston starts his workday at his desk, dealing with messages from the pneumatic tube, and making necessary corrections to past news articles as per the Party's instructions.

131-136.description: Winston is adjusting the Ministry of Plenty's figures, reflecting on the nature of his work and the falsification of information.
text_phrases: mouth very close to the mouthpiece of the speakwrite

131-136.description: Winston observes his colleagues in the Records Department, each absorbed in their specific tasks of altering historical records.
Winston reflects on the nature of his work, the pleasure he derives from it, and the intricate tasks of forgery he is assigned.

137-146.description: Winston is tasked with rewriting an article about Big Brother's Order for the Day, which originally praised Comrade Withers and the FFCC. Withers has since become an unperson, leading Winston to need to alter the article significantly.
137-146.location: Winston's office at the Ministry of Truth
137-146.dialog_summary: Winston contemplates the reasons behind Withers' disgrace and the nature of political purges, reflecting on the mechanics of government and the rewriting of history.
text_phrases: Winston stroked his nose gently with a paper clip
Comrade Tillotson was still crouching secretively over his speakwrite
raised his head for a moment

137-146.description: Winston decides to invent a new hero, Comrade Ogilvy, to replace the content of the original article. He uses the speakwrite to create a fictional biography of Ogilvy, portraying him as a model Party member.
137-146.location: Winston's office at the Ministry of Truth
137-146.dialog_summary: Winston dictates the life story of the fictional Comrade Ogilvy, emphasizing his loyalty and heroic death, which serves as a propaganda tool for the Party.
text_phrases: began dictating in Big Brother's familiar style

147-169.description: Winston debates internally about whether to award Comrade Ogilvy the Order of Conspicuous Merit, ultimately deciding against it due to the complexity it would introduce.
In a noisy, crowded underground canteen, Winston and Syme queue for lunch, discussing razor blades and the hanging of prisoners.
147-169.dialog_summary: Syme asks Winston for razor blades and discusses the inadequacy of watching a hanging on film compared to witnessing it in person. They also discuss the progress of the Newspeak dictionary.

170-180.description: Winston and Syme engage in a deep conversation about the systematic reduction of language in Newspeak, reflecting on the implications for thought and freedom.
170-180.dialog_summary: Syme enthusiastically explains the purpose and beauty of Newspeak, aiming to reduce the range of thought by simplifying language. Winston listens, somewhat sympathetically but with internal reservations about the destruction of words and traditional language.
text_phrases: He bit hungrily into his bread

170-180.description: While Winston and Syme discuss, Winston observes another conversation at a nearby table, reflecting on the orthodoxy of the speech and the mechanical nature of the participants.
170-180.dialog_summary: A man with a strident voice talks continuously in what seems like orthodox Party rhetoric, while a young woman, possibly his secretary, agrees with him. Winston perceives the man's speech as mechanical and devoid of genuine thought.
text_phrases: young woman who was perhaps his secretary

181-195.description: Syme and Winston are having a conversation in a crowded room when Parsons joins them, leading to a discussion about work and personal anecdotes.
181-195.dialog_summary: Syme discusses the word 'duckspeak' in Newspeak with Winston. Parsons arrives, discusses his children's activities and the upcoming Hate Week, and collects a subscription from Winston.

196-204.scene_title: Discussion and Announcement in the Canteen
196-204.description: Parsons, Winston, and Syme are in a canteen discussing the ongoing war and the recent production achievements announced by the Ministry of Plenty through a telescreen. The canteen is crowded, grimy, and filled with the smell of bad gin and coffee.
196-204.dialog_summary: Parsons mimics shooting a rifle, discussing the war. Syme is distracted with his paper. Winston agrees about not taking chances. An announcement from the Ministry of Plenty declares a production victory and praises Big Brother.
text_phrases: Parsons made the motion of aiming a rifle
clicked his tongue for the explosion
Syme abstractedly, without looking up from his strip of paper
trumpet call floated from the telescreen
Winston was smoking a Victory Cigarette
Winston had taken up his spoon and was dabbling in the pale-colored gravy

205-218.description: Parsons and Winston discuss the Ministry of Plenty's achievements and the scarcity of razor blades while a quacking voice resumes in the background.
205-218.dialog_summary: Parsons praises the Ministry of Plenty and asks Winston for razor blades, which Winston says he doesn't have. They briefly discuss the scarcity.
text_phrases: took his pipe out of his mouth
quacking voice from the next table

205-218.description: Winston ponders who will be vaporized and who will not, and is suddenly caught off guard by the intense gaze of the dark-haired girl from the Fiction Department.
text_phrases: looking at him in a sidelong way
sweat started out on Winston's backbone

205-218.scene_title: Parsons' Anecdote and Return to Work
205-218.description: Parsons shares a story about his children's mischief, and the signal from the telescreen abruptly ends their break, prompting them to return to work.
205-218.dialog_summary: Parsons tells Winston about his children setting fire to a woman's skirt and discusses the training given to young spies.
text_phrases: chuckling round the stem of his pipe
telescreen let out a piercing whistle
remaining tobacco fell out of Winston's cigarette

219-227.description: Winston experiences a strong internal conflict and temptation to act out violently to suppress his haunting memories.
text_phrases: shout a string of filthy words
bang his head against the wall
hurl the inkpot through the window

219-227.description: Winston recalls seeing a Party member in the street suffering from a facial spasm, reflecting on the involuntary nature of such symptoms.
text_phrases: left side of the man's face was suddenly contorted

219-227.scene_title: Winston's Recollection of the Basement Kitchen
219-227.description: Winston recalls an intimate encounter in a basement kitchen, reflecting on his marriage and the Party's views on relationships and sexuality.
text_phrases: went with her through the doorway
across a backyard into a basement kitchen

228-242.description: Winston reflects on his mechanical and unfulfilling intimate experiences with his wife Katharine, who insists on fulfilling their duty to produce a child despite the lack of emotional connection.
228-242.dialog_summary: Katharine insists on their duty to produce a child, referring to it as 'making a baby' and 'our duty to the Party'.
text_phrases: embrace her was like embracing a jointed wooden image
she was clasping him against her
remind him of it in the morning

228-242.scene_title: Winston's Encounter with an Old Woman
228-242.description: Winston, in a dimly lit room, is shocked to realize the woman he is with is much older than he expected, revealing his deep-seated loneliness and desperation.
text_phrases: threw herself down on the bed
the paint was plastered so thick on her face

228-242.description: Winston observes a riot at a street market where proles are fighting over tin saucepans, highlighting the desperation and trivial concerns that occupy their lives.
228-242.dialog_summary: Women accuse the stallkeeper of favoritism and demand access to more saucepans.
text_phrases: tremendous shout of hundreds of voices
bumped and jostled by the rest

243-250.description: Winston reflects on the state of the proles and the Party's manipulation, then begins to write in his diary, copying from a children's history textbook.
text_phrases: Winston reached down and cautiously scratched his varicose ulcer
He took out of the drawer a copy of a children's history textbook
began copying a passage into the diary

243-250.description: Winston copies a passage from a children's history textbook describing the harsh conditions of pre-Revolution London and the disparity between the rich and the poor.
text_phrases: a copy of a children's history textbook
dressed in a long black coat which was called a frock coat
a queer, shiny hat shaped like a stovepipe, which was called a top hat

251-256.description: Winston reflects on the falsification of history and the erasure of the past by the Party, while scratching his ankle and pondering over the statistics broadcasted by the telescreens.
text_phrases: telescreens bruised your ears with statistics

251-256.description: Winston recalls seeing the three pardoned Party members, Jones, Aaronson, and Rutherford, at the Chestnut Tree Café, sitting silently with glasses of gin.
251-256.dialog_summary: No dialogue, just silent observation by Winston.
text_phrases: sitting in silence before glasses of the gin
chessboard on the table beside them

257-268.description: Winston discovers a photograph that contradicts the Party's official history, which causes him deep reflection and fear.
object_part_of_object: portrait of Big Brother;children's history book
text_phrases: Winston was unrolling a wad of documents
dropped the photograph into the memory hole

269-278.description: Winston feels a sudden surge of courage and thinks of O'Brien, believing him to be an ally. He reflects on the Party's control over reality and writes in his diary, addressing O'Brien.
Winston is momentarily transported back to his childhood by the smell of real coffee coming from a passage as he walks through the street.
Winston walks through the slums, observing the life around him and overhearing a conversation between two women.
269-278.dialog_summary: Two women discuss personal problems and the difficulty of being criticized without understanding someone else's situation.
text_phrases: cobbled street of little two-story houses

269-278.description: The street erupts in commotion as people react to an unseen threat, darting into doorways and looking towards the sky.

279-291.description: Winston experiences a rocket bomb attack while walking in a prole area. He takes cover as advised by a prole and observes the aftermath of the attack.
279-291.dialog_summary: A prole warns Winston about an incoming rocket bomb, advising him to take cover.
text_phrases: Winston promptly flung himself on his face
covered with fragments of glass from the nearest window
a black plume of smoke hung in the sky
a human hand severed at the wrist

279-291.description: Winston observes a heated argument among proles about the Lottery numbers, reflecting on the significance of the Lottery to the proles.
279-291.dialog_summary: Two proles argue about whether a number ending in seven has won in the Lottery recently, with a third prole trying to calm them down.
text_phrases: grimy swing doors, endlessly opening and shutting
two of the men were in violent altercation

279-291.description: Winston contemplates entering a pub to talk to an old man about the past, reflecting on the lost world of capitalism and the changes since the Revolution.
279-291.dialog_summary: Winston considers asking an old man about life before the Revolution.
text_phrases: dingy little pub whose windows appeared to be frosted over but in reality were merely coated with dust
old man, bent but active, with white mustaches that bristled forward like those of a prawn, pushed open the swing door and went in

292-312.description: Winston enters a prole pub, experiencing a sudden change in atmosphere as the patrons notice him and a game of darts pauses momentarily.
292-312.dialog_summary: The old man argues with the barman about not being able to get a pint of beer, which leads to a humorous exchange about measurements and the barman's ignorance of older beer measures.
text_phrases: barman, a large, stout, hook-nosed young man

292-312.description: Winston engages in a conversation with the old man about the past, discussing changes in beer quality and prices, and the old man reminisces about the old days.
292-312.dialog_summary: Winston and the old man discuss the changes since the old man's youth, including the quality and cost of beer, and the old man reminisces about wearing a top hat long ago.
text_phrases: pale blue eyes moved from the darts board to the bar

313-328.description: Winston and an old man discuss the societal changes and personal experiences from the past compared to the present, focusing on the treatment of common people by the upper class.
313-328.dialog_summary: Winston tries to understand if people were treated better in the past compared to the present. The old man reminisces about his experiences with the upper class and their lackeys, and how they treated common people. He also reflects on personal freedom and the physical ailments of old age.
text_phrases: drank off about a quarter of his beer
looked meditatively at the darts board
sat back against the window sill
shuffled rapidly into the stinking urinal
his feet carried him out into the street

329-343.description: Winston finds himself outside the junk shop where he previously bought a diary, feeling a twinge of fear for returning.
329-343.location: Narrow street with dark little shops

329-343.description: Winston enters the junk shop, encountering the proprietor and engaging in a conversation about various items, including a piece of coral embedded in glass.
329-343.dialog_summary: The proprietor recognizes Winston and they discuss the state of the antique trade and the items in the shop. Winston buys a piece of coral embedded in glass.

329-343.description: Winston follows the proprietor upstairs to explore another room filled with a few pieces of furniture and a large bed.
329-343.location: Upstairs room in the junk shop
329-343.dialog_summary: The proprietor suggests looking at another room upstairs which contains a few pieces of furniture.

344-365.description: Winston visits an old man who is selling off his furniture. The room is warmly lit and invokes a sense of nostalgia in Winston.
344-365.dialog_summary: The old man explains that he has been selling furniture since his wife died and mentions the lack of a telescreen and details about various pieces of furniture. Winston and the old man discuss a picture of a building that used to be a church.
text_phrases: steel engraving of an oval building

366-374.scene_title: Winston's Encounter with the Dark-Haired Girl
366-374.description: Winston leaves Mr. Charrington's shop and encounters the dark-haired girl from the Fiction Department on the street, which leads him to suspect she is spying on him.
366-374.dialog_summary: No direct dialogue, but Winston's internal monologue reveals his suspicions and fears about the dark-haired girl.
text_phrases: diary and without knowing whether the proprietor of the shop could be trusted

366-374.description: After the unsettling encounter, Winston returns home, consumes Victory Gin, and reflects on the nature of fear and pain while struggling with his own physical discomfort.
366-374.dialog_summary: No dialogue, but Winston's internal thoughts explore the concept of fear, pain, and the human body's response to crisis.
text_phrases: swallowed nearly a teacupful of Victory Gin
sat down at the table in the alcove
staring at the marbled cover of the book
trying without success to shut the voice out of his consciousness

375-392.description: Winston opens his diary to write, but is distracted by a song from the telescreen and thoughts of the inevitable capture by the Thought Police.
text_phrases: The woman on the telescreen had started a new song
He put a cigarette in his mouth
Half the tobacco promptly fell out

375-392.description: Winston encounters the dark-haired girl in a corridor, who stumbles and falls, revealing her injury. Winston helps her up, and she secretly passes him a note.
375-392.dialog_summary: The girl reassures Winston that she is alright after falling and thanks him before continuing on her way.
text_phrases: A solitary figure was coming toward him
the girl stumbled and fell almost flat on her face
she walked on in the direction in which she had been going
the girl had slipped something into his hand

393-399.description: Winston contemplates the potential meanings of a note he received, suspecting it could be from the Thought Police or an underground organization. He struggles with his emotions and tries to focus on his work.
393-399.dialog_summary: Winston internally debates the origin and meaning of the note, no direct dialogue.
text_phrases: rolled up the completed bundle of work
slid it into the pneumatic tube
readjusted his spectacles on his nose
drew the next batch of work toward him

393-399.description: Winston experiences a tumultuous lunch in the canteen, struggling to hide his agitation and encountering Parsons, who talks about Hate Week preparations.
393-399.dialog_summary: Parsons talks enthusiastically about Hate Week preparations, particularly about a papier-mâché model of Big Brother's head.
objects: papier-mâché model of Big Brother's head
object_part_of_object: papier-mâché model of Big Brother's head;Hate Week preparations
text_phrases: Lunch in the hot, crowded, noise-filled canteen was torment
papier-mâché model of Big Brother's head, two meters wide
caught a glimpse of the girl

393-399.description: Winston spends his evening at the Community Center engaging in various activities, trying to distract himself from thoughts of the girl and the note.
393-399.dialog_summary: Winston participates in a discussion group and listens to a lecture about 'Ingsoc in relation to chess', but his mind is preoccupied.
text_phrases: played two games of table tennis
sat for half an hour through a lecture

400-404.description: Winston contemplates how to safely communicate with the girl he is interested in, considering various methods and their risks, and finally decides that the canteen might be the safest place to attempt a conversation.
Winston experiences several days of emotional turmoil as he misses opportunities to speak with the girl in the canteen, observes her absence, and struggles with his feelings.
text_phrases: did not appear in the canteen

400-404.description: Winston nearly succeeds in speaking to the girl in the canteen but is interrupted when he is recognized and called by a colleague, forcing him to abandon his attempt.
400-404.dialog_summary: Winston is called by a colleague named Wilsher, which prevents him from sitting with the girl.
text_phrases: sitting at a table well out from the wall

400-404.description: Winston finally manages to sit at the same table as the girl after a small man who was heading towards her table trips and spills his tray, creating an opportunity for Winston.
text_phrases: making straight for the girl's table
streams of soup and coffee were flowing

400-404.description: Winston sits with the girl and tries to initiate a conversation, battling his fear and urgency as they both eat their meals.
400-404.dialog_summary: Winston and the girl exchange a few necessary words in low voices while eating.
text_phrases: spooned the watery stuff into their mouths

405-432.description: Winston and the girl discreetly arrange a meeting in Victory Square near the monument amidst a conversation about avoiding surveillance.
405-432.dialog_summary: Winston and the girl discuss the logistics of their meeting, emphasizing caution due to the presence of telescreens and the need to blend into a crowd.

405-432.description: Winston arrives early at Victory Square, anxiously waiting for the girl by the monument while observing his surroundings.
text_phrases: base of the enormous fluted column
statue of a man on horseback
reading or pretending to read a poster

405-432.description: Winston and the girl, amidst a chaotic crowd reacting to a convoy of prisoners, manage to come physically close and exchange crucial information.
405-432.dialog_summary: The girl gives Winston detailed instructions for their next meeting, emphasizing the need for precision and caution.
text_phrases: enormous prole and an almost equally enormous woman

433-443.description: Winston and the girl meet secretly in the woods, exchanging cautious words and subtle gestures, surrounded by the natural beauty and isolation of their surroundings.
433-443.dialog_summary: The girl warns Winston to keep quiet to avoid potential hidden microphones and explains why the area is likely safe from surveillance. They make small talk, and Winston slowly approaches her, eventually taking her hand.
text_phrases: bushes and quickly led the way
tiny grassy knoll surrounded by tall saplings
scarlet sash that was just tight enough to bring out the curve of her hips
bluebells had cascaded on to the ground

444-467.description: Winston and Julia share a moment of intimacy and personal revelations in a secluded outdoor setting. They discuss their feelings and past thoughts about each other, leading to a deeper connection.
444-467.dialog_summary: Winston and Julia discuss their initial perceptions and feelings about each other, revealing personal secrets and forming a bond. Julia also shares her involvement with the Junior Anti-Sex League and her activities.
text_phrases: scarlet sash of the Junior Anti-Sex League

468-493.description: Winston and Julia are hiding in the shade of hazel bushes, discussing the presence of a nearby stream while being cautious of their surroundings.
468-493.location: Shade of hazel bushes near a field
468-493.dialog_summary: Winston and Julia whisper about the nearby stream and the presence of fish, reflecting on the landscape resembling a dream-like place called the Golden Country.
text_phrases: standing in the shade of hazel bushes
boughs of the elm trees swayed

468-493.description: A thrush lands near Winston and Julia and begins to sing beautifully, captivating them with its melody.
468-493.location: Near a field in the shade
text_phrases: thrush had alighted on a bough
in the sun, they in the shade

468-493.description: Winston and Julia share a deeply personal conversation about their pasts and views on purity, followed by a physical connection and a decision to return to their hideout.
468-493.dialog_summary: Winston and Julia discuss their past sexual encounters and their disdain for purity and goodness, expressing a desire for widespread corruption.
text_phrases: freckled face with its faint, bold smile

494-502.scene_title: Winston and Julia in the Hideout
494-502.description: Winston wakes up first and observes Julia sleeping peacefully, reflecting on her features and their recent intimate moments which he views as a political act against the Party.
494-502.dialog_summary: Julia discusses the safety of using the hideout again and plans their separate departures to avoid suspicion.
text_phrases: sat up and watched the freckled face
still peacefully asleep, pillowed on the palm of her hand
knotted the scarlet sash about her waist

494-502.description: Winston and Julia manage to meet secretly in crowded places, speaking in coded manners and always under the threat of Party surveillance.
494-502.dialog_summary: Julia instructs Winston on how to behave during their secret meetings in public places, using signals like blowing her nose to indicate safety.
text_phrases: meet after work, four evenings hence
open market which was generally crowded and noisy
pretending to be in search of shoelaces or sewing thread
if she judged that the coast was clear she would blow her nose
in the middle of the crowd, it would be safe to talk

503-516.description: Winston and Julia meet in the church tower, discussing their lives and views in a hot, stagnant room filled with the smell of pigeon dung.
503-516.dialog_summary: Julia talks about her work, her disdain for the Party, and her personal history including her first love affair. Winston learns about Julia's work in Pornosec and her views on evading the Party's restrictions. They discuss their personal lives but avoid the topic of marriage.

517-535.scene_title: Discussion on the Party's Sexual Puritanism
517-535.description: Julia explains to Winston the Party's strategy of using sexual privation to induce hysteria, which is then transformed into war fever and leader worship.
517-535.dialog_summary: Julia discusses the Party's use of sexual repression to control people's energy and emotions, linking it to political orthodoxy and control.

517-535.scene_title: Memory of a Past Incident with Katharine
517-535.description: Winston recalls a past incident during a hike with his then-wife Katharine, where he contemplated pushing her off a cliff but ultimately did not.
517-535.dialog_summary: Winston shares with Julia a memory of a hike with Katharine where he thought about pushing her off a cliff but didn't. Julia questions why he didn't do it.
text_phrases: lost their way on a community hike
sheer drop of ten or twenty meters
tufts of loose-strife growing in the cracks of the cliff
hottest, sleepiest hour of the afternoon

536-551.description: Winston and Julia discuss the concept of life and death, contrasting their feelings about mortality and the vitality of life.
536-551.dialog_summary: Winston expresses fear of death, Julia counters with the pleasures of being alive and urges Winston to focus on living rather than dying.
text_phrases: could feel her breasts, ripe yet firm, through her overalls

536-551.description: Julia takes a practical approach to planning their next secret meeting, drawing a map on the floor.
536-551.dialog_summary: Julia suggests going back to their previous meeting place in the wood and explains a new route to get there, drawing a map to illustrate.
text_phrases: scraped together a small square of dust
drawing a map on the floor

536-551.description: Winston observes a woman singing while hanging diapers in the courtyard, reflecting on the absence of a telescreen in the room.
536-551.dialog_summary: The woman sings a popular tune while working, and Winston reflects on the silence in the room due to the lack of a telescreen.
text_phrases: stumping to and fro between a washtub and a clothesline
pegging out a series of square white things
peeped out, secure in the protection of the muslin curtain

552-572.description: Winston feels a mix of anger and tenderness when Julia tells him she can't meet him as planned, reflecting on his deepening feelings for her.
552-572.dialog_summary: Julia informs Winston she cannot meet him the next afternoon due to the usual reasons, which disappoints him.
text_phrases: gave the tips of his fingers a quick squeeze

552-572.description: Julia arrives with a bag full of forbidden items including real sugar, coffee, and bread, surprising Winston with these rare commodities.
552-572.dialog_summary: Julia shows Winston the contents of her tool bag, revealing smuggled goods like real sugar and coffee, and instructs Winston to turn his back.
text_phrases: carrying a tool bag of coarse brown canvas
tumbled out some spanners and a screwdriver
the smell was already filling the room

552-572.description: While Julia prepares surprises, Winston looks through the muslin curtain and observes a woman in the yard, reflecting on the nature of happiness and singing in their society.
552-572.dialog_summary: Winston reflects silently as he watches a woman singing while hanging clothes, pondering the rarity of spontaneous singing among Party members.
text_phrases: Winston gazed abstractedly through the muslin curtain
the red-armed woman was still marching to and fro between the washtub and the line

573-591.description: Winston turns around to see Julia transformed with makeup, which surprises him as he expected to see her naked. Her appearance with cosmetics is startling and makes her look more feminine.
573-591.dialog_summary: Julia tells Winston she has applied makeup and plans to wear more feminine clothing like silk stockings and high-heeled shoes.

573-591.description: Winston and Julia undress and climb into a large mahogany bed, discussing their surroundings and the novelty of such a bed in their experience.
573-591.dialog_summary: Julia and Winston discuss the rarity of double beds and their plans for the evening. Julia reacts to a rat in the room.
text_phrases: blanket they lay on was threadbare and smooth
seized a shoe from the floor

592-611.description: Winston and Julia discuss their dislike for rats and make plans to seal a hole in their hideout. Julia gets dressed, makes coffee, and they enjoy the rare luxury of real sugar in their coffee.
592-611.dialog_summary: Winston expresses his fear of rats. Julia reassures him and plans to seal the hole. They discuss the age and history of objects in the room.
text_phrases: pointing out the best way of repairing the gateleg table
plumping herself down in the ragged armchair
brought the glass paperweight over to the bed
went over to look at the engraving

592-611.description: Winston reflects on the glass paperweight and its symbolism while thinking about the disappearance of his colleague, Syme, who has been erased from existence.
text_phrases: lay gazing into the glass paperweight

592-611.description: The city is abuzz with preparations for Hate Week. Winston and Julia are busy with their respective tasks in the Ministry and the Fiction Department.

612-615.description: Volunteers, led by Parsons, are busy preparing the street for Hate Week by stitching banners, painting posters, erecting flagstaffs, and slinging wires across the street.
612-615.dialog_summary: Parsons boasts about the decorations and his involvement in the preparations.

612-615.description: A new poster depicting a monstrous Eurasian soldier has appeared all over London, stirring up patriotic frenzy among the proles.
text_phrases: monstrous figure of a Eurasian soldier
submachine gun pointed from his hip

612-615.scene_title: Secret Meetings in Mr. Charrington's Room
612-615.description: Julia and Winston meet secretly in the room over Mr. Charrington's shop, where they find solace and temporary escape from their oppressive reality.
612-615.dialog_summary: Winston and Julia discuss their secret hideaway and the relief it provides from their daily lives.
text_phrases: stripped bed under the open window

616-619.description: Winston and Julia share a moment of despair and sensuality in their sanctuary room, reflecting on the inevitability of their situation and engaging in daydreams of impossible escapes.
616-619.dialog_summary: Winston and Julia discuss various escape fantasies including marriage, suicide, and altering their identities, but acknowledge the impracticality and impossibility of these ideas.
text_phrases: clock is within five minutes of striking

616-619.description: Winston and Julia discuss the possibility of rebellion against the Party and their skepticism about the existence of organized opposition.
616-619.dialog_summary: Winston shares his thoughts about O'Brien and the Brotherhood, while Julia expresses her doubts about the reality of widespread opposition and recounts her experiences at Party rallies and the Two Minutes Hate.
text_phrases: engaging in active rebellion against the Party

620-638.description: Winston talks to Julia about his role in falsifying the past and the implications of such actions, trying to convey the gravity of erasing history.
620-638.dialog_summary: Winston explains the process and implications of falsifying history to Julia, who seems indifferent and fails to grasp the seriousness of the situation.

620-638.description: Winston encounters O'Brien in the corridor of the Ministry, where O'Brien expresses a desire to speak with him about Newspeak.
620-638.dialog_summary: O'Brien initiates a conversation with Winston about his interest in Newspeak, marking a significant personal interaction.

639-657.description: O'Brien and Winston engage in a seemingly casual conversation that veers into dangerous territory with the mention of obsolete words and an offer to view a new edition of the Newspeak dictionary. The conversation ends with O'Brien giving Winston his address under the watchful eye of a telescreen.
639-657.dialog_summary: O'Brien compliments Winston's writing and mentions a mutual acquaintance, leading to a discussion about the Newspeak dictionary. O'Brien offers Winston a chance to see the new edition and provides his address.
text_phrases: resettled his spectacles on his nose

639-657.description: Winston wakes up teary-eyed from a vivid dream about his past, lying next to Julia. He recalls a significant memory of his mother and a traumatic event from his childhood.
639-657.dialog_summary: Winston starts to tell Julia about his dream but stops, overwhelmed by the complexity and the painful memory of his mother that it evokes.
text_phrases: Winston had woken up with his eyes full of tears
lay back with his eyes shut

658-664.description: Winston recalls the difficult times of his youth, marked by air raids, scarcity of food, and the mysterious disappearance of his father.
658-664.location: Various locations in a war-torn city
text_phrases: scrounging round dustbins and rubbish heaps
picking out the ribs of cabbage leaves
waiting for the passing of trucks
spilt a few fragments of oilcake

658-664.scene_title: Winston's Childhood Home and Family Dynamics
658-664.description: Winston remembers the small, dark room where he lived with his mother and sister, and the struggles over food and his mother's spiritless demeanor after his father's disappearance.
658-664.dialog_summary: Winston frequently argues with his mother about the scarcity of food, demanding more for himself despite his sister's needs.
text_phrases: mother's statuesque body bending over the gas ring

665-682.scene_title: Winston's Dream and Conversation with Julia
665-682.description: Winston recalls a vivid dream about his mother and discusses it with Julia, who is half-asleep beside him. The conversation shifts to their bleak future and the inevitability of their betrayal under the Party's oppression.
665-682.dialog_summary: Winston shares his dream and thoughts about his mother with Julia, who responds indifferently and eventually discusses the futility of their resistance against the Party, emphasizing the inevitability of betrayal and the importance of maintaining their feelings for each other.

683-700.description: Winston and Julia are led into a softly lit, long-shaped room where O'Brien is seated at a table under a green-shaded lamp, surrounded by papers. The room is richly decorated, and the telescreen is dimmed. O'Brien interacts with his speakwrite before noticing Winston and Julia, who are anxious about their risky visit.
683-700.location: O'Brien's room in the Inner Party dwelling
683-700.dialog_summary: O'Brien acknowledges he can turn off the telescreen and discusses with Winston and Julia about their motives for visiting, which include joining a conspiracy against the Party. O'Brien introduces his servant Martin as part of their group.
text_phrases: room they were standing in was long-shaped and softly lit
telescreen was dimmed to a low murmur
dark-blue carpet gave one the impression of treading on velvet
O'Brien was sitting at a table under a green-shaded lamp
mass of papers on either side of him

701-735.description: In a dimly lit room, O'Brien introduces Winston and Julia to wine, a rare commodity, and discusses its scarcity among the Outer Party. He then toasts to Emmanuel Goldstein, initiating a solemn moment.
701-735.dialog_summary: O'Brien explains the rarity of wine to Winston and Julia and toasts to Emmanuel Goldstein.
text_phrases: O'Brien took the decanter by the neck

701-735.description: O'Brien questions Winston and Julia about their commitment to the Brotherhood, asking them if they are prepared to undertake extreme actions for the cause.
701-735.dialog_summary: O'Brien asks Winston and Julia a series of intense questions to test their loyalty and commitment to the Brotherhood, to which they agree to all except separating forever.
text_phrases: O'Brien had turned himself a little in his chair

701-735.description: O'Brien discusses the potential need to change Winston's identity and the extreme measures the Brotherhood might require, including altering physical appearances.
701-735.dialog_summary: O'Brien explains the possibility of changing Winston's identity and the lengths the Brotherhood might go to ensure loyalty, including physical alterations.
text_phrases: added in a voice with somewhat more expression
silver box of cigarettes on the table
O'Brien pushed them toward the others
stood up and began to pace slowly

736-743.description: In a dimly lit room, O'Brien, a powerful and confident figure, walks back and forth while explaining the harsh realities and the secretive nature of the Brotherhood to Winston and Julia. He speaks of the inevitable capture and confession that members face, and the undying idea that binds the Brotherhood together.
736-743.dialog_summary: O'Brien explains the operations and expectations of the Brotherhood to Winston and Julia, emphasizing the secrecy, inevitable capture, and the ideological commitment required. He mentions that the Brotherhood is bound not by mutual recognition or traditional organization, but by a shared, indestructible idea.
text_phrases: one hand in the pocket of his black overalls

744-766.description: Winston and O'Brien discuss the importance of hiding and the future plans involving a secret book in O'Brien's office.
744-766.dialog_summary: O'Brien and Winston discuss the necessity of changing hiding places frequently and the plan to secretly pass a copy of Goldstein's book to Winston.
text_phrases: small box from the top of a cabinet
hand on the switch that controlled the telescreen
writing table with its green-shaded lamp and the speakwrite

744-766.description: Winston reflects on his physical and mental exhaustion as he walks through the streets carrying the secret book.
text_phrases: the book, which he had now had in his possession for six days

767-771.description: During a demonstration in a central London square, it is suddenly revealed that Oceania is now at war with Eastasia instead of Eurasia. The crowd reacts violently to this news.
767-771.dialog_summary: A messenger delivers a note to the speaker, who reads it and subtly changes the enemy's name in his speech.
text_phrases: white faces and the scarlet banners were luridly floodlit
gripped the neck of the microphone
banners torn to shreds and trampled underfoot
Spies performed prodigies of activity in clambering over the rooftops and cutting the streamers

767-771.description: Winston receives a briefcase from a stranger during the chaos of changing propaganda materials. He then heads to the Ministry of Truth to rectify historical records.
767-771.dialog_summary: A man tells Winston he dropped his briefcase. Winston takes it without speaking.
text_phrases: man whose face he did not see had tapped him on the shoulder
mattresses were brought up from the cellars and pitched all over the corridors
another shower of paper cylinders had covered the desk like a snowdrift

772-787.description: Winston climbs the stairs to his room above Mr. Charrington's shop, prepares to make coffee, and begins reading a heavy black volume titled 'The Theory and Practice of Oligarchical Collectivism' by Emmanuel Goldstein.
772-787.location: Winston's room above Mr. Charrington's shop
text_phrases: put on a pan of water for coffee
sat down in the sluttish armchair
undid the straps of the brief case
pages were worn at the edges
put his feet up on the fender

788-791.description: The scene describes the exploitation of disputed territories for their resources and labor to fuel continuous warfare. It highlights the strategic importance of these regions and the perpetual cycle of conquest and exploitation.
text_phrases: important vegetable products such as rubber
scores or hundreds of millions of ill-paid and hard-working coolies
expended like so much coal or oil

788-791.description: This scene explains the primary aim of modern warfare according to the principles of doublethink, highlighting the paradox of recognizing and not recognizing the true purpose simultaneously. It discusses the use of surplus production to fuel continuous war without improving the general standard of living.
characters: directing brains of the Inner Party
text_phrases: use up the products of the machine

788-791.description: The scene reflects on the decline of society despite technological advancements, emphasizing the impact of continuous wars and the regimented society on stifling scientific progress and overall development.
text_phrases: world more primitive today than it was fifty years ago
scientific and technical progress depended on the empirical habit of thought
ravages of the atomic war of the Nineteen-fifties

792-795.description: The scene discusses the economic strategies used during the final phase of capitalism to keep the masses in poverty by restricting goods and the continuous warfare strategy to prevent the distribution of produced goods.
text_phrases: capital equipment was not added to
great blocks of the population were prevented from working
Goods must be produced, but they must not be distributed

792-795.scene_title: War as a Tool for Economic Control
792-795.description: The scene describes how war is used as a method to destroy the products of human labor, preventing the masses from becoming too comfortable and intelligent, which could threaten the existing power structures.
text_phrases: The essential act of war is destruction
weapons of war are not actually destroyed

792-795.scene_title: Inner Party Lifestyle and War Psychology
792-795.description: The scene illustrates the austere yet privileged lifestyle of the Inner Party members, contrasting with the Outer Party and the proles, set against the backdrop of a continuous state of war which justifies the power dynamics.
text_phrases: the better texture of his clothes

796-800.description: Scientists and strategists in a dystopian world explore various advanced and destructive technologies, none of which come to fruition.
text_phrases: vehicle that shall bore its way under the soil
airplane as independent of its base
focusing the sun's rays through lenses
producing artificial earthquakes and tidal waves

796-800.description: Despite the ongoing war and the development of the atomic bomb, the art of war has seen little advancement, with older technologies still in use.
text_phrases: bombing planes have been largely superseded by self-propelled projectiles
movable battleship has given way to the almost unsinkable Floating Fortress

796-800.description: The superstates engage in a perpetual war, using strategies of surprise attacks and treachery without risking serious defeat, maintaining a balance of power.
796-800.location: Strategic planning rooms of the superstates
text_phrases: large operation is usually a surprise attack

801-804.description: Winston experiences a moment of solitude and safety while reading a forbidden book in a room without a telescreen. He is interrupted by the distant sound of a rocket bomb and the arrival of Julia.
801-804.dialog_summary: No direct dialogue, but Julia arrives and flings herself into Winston's arms.
text_phrases: brown tool bag on the floor

805-818.description: Winston and Julia are in their bedroom, discussing a book that is crucial for members of the Brotherhood. Winston reads aloud from the book while Julia listens, half-asleep.
805-818.dialog_summary: Winston tells Julia they must read the book. Julia asks Winston to read it aloud and explain it to her as they have a few hours before them.
text_phrases: knelt down beside the oilstove to make the coffee
propped the book against his knees

819-822.scene_title: Historical Knowledge and the Rise of New Doctrines
819-822.description: The scene discusses the rise of new political doctrines influenced by the accumulation of historical knowledge and the understanding of history's cyclical nature. It highlights the technical possibility of human equality by the early twentieth century and the shift in societal structures due to machine production.
819-822.location: A theoretical or conceptual space representing historical evolution

819-822.description: This scene describes the ideological shift in the twentieth century where authoritarian political thoughts dominated, discrediting the idea of an earthly paradise just as it became achievable. It reflects on the resurgence of oppressive practices and the hardening of societal outlooks.
819-822.location: A conceptual space representing political and social ideologies

819-822.scene_title: The Rise of Ingsoc and Totalitarianism
819-822.description: This scene outlines the emergence of Ingsoc and similar totalitarian systems following a period of wars and revolutions. It discusses the consolidation of power among bureaucrats, scientists, and other professionals, highlighting the transformation of society into High, Middle, and Low strata.
819-822.location: A conceptual space representing the restructuring of society

823-826.description: The text describes the hierarchical structure of Oceanic society, detailing the roles of Big Brother, the Inner Party, the Outer Party, and the proles. It also explains the mechanisms of control and the stability of the ruling class.
text_phrases: Big Brother is a face on the hoardings

823-826.description: The text outlines the potential threats to the ruling class's power and the strategies employed to mitigate these threats, including the prevention of revolts and the management of discontent through continuous warfare and educational control.

827-831.description: A theoretical explanation of how oligarchical systems like the Party maintain power over generations, focusing on the perpetuation of a worldview rather than hereditary succession.
Describes the pervasive surveillance and control exerted over Party members by the Thought Police, emphasizing the lack of privacy and constant scrutiny.
text_phrases: behavior toward his wife and children

827-831.description: An explanation of the concept of 'crimestop', a mental discipline taught to Party members to prevent rebellious or heretical thoughts.
text_phrases: bored or repelled by any train of thought
control over one's own mental processes

827-831.description: Details the methods by which the Party continuously rewrites history to maintain the illusion of its infallibility and the necessity of its rule.
text_phrases: safeguard the infallibility of the Party

832-835.description: A detailed exposition on the concept of 'doublethink', a critical aspect of the Party's control over reality and history.
text_phrases: forget that one has done so

832-835.scene_title: The Paradox of Knowledge and Ignorance
832-835.description: The scene describes the paradoxical nature of the Party's ideology, where knowledge and ignorance coexist, and the societal implications of such a system.
text_phrases: systematically undermines the solidarity of the family

836-857.scene_title: Winston and Julia in the Bedroom
836-857.description: Winston observes Julia sleeping and reflects on the secrets of the Party and the nature of sanity.
836-857.dialog_summary: Winston attempts to wake Julia by calling her name, but she does not respond as she is asleep.
text_phrases: She was lying on her side, naked from the waist upwards
He shut the book, put it carefully on the floor
pulled the coverlet over both of them
A yellow beam from the sinking sun slanted in through the window

836-857.description: Winston and Julia wake up and discuss their immediate needs and observations about their surroundings.
836-857.dialog_summary: Julia complains about being hungry and the stove being out of oil. They discuss getting more oil and the temperature.
text_phrases: Julia woke at the sound, stretched herself luxuriously, and got out of bed
The stove's gone out and the water's cold
She picked the stove up and shook it
Winston also got up and dressed himself
he strolled across to the window

858-879.description: Winston and Julia are suddenly confronted by a voice from a hidden telescreen in their room, revealing that they have been watched. The voice commands them to stand in the middle of the room and not touch each other as the room is surrounded by authorities.
858-879.dialog_summary: The hidden voice reveals that Winston and Julia are being watched and commands them to stand still and not touch each other. It announces that the house is surrounded by authorities.
text_phrases: white all round the irises of Julia's eyes
snap as though a catch had been turned back
picture had fallen to the floor
stand out in the middle of the room
clasp your hands behind your heads
washtub had been flung across the yard
head of a ladder had been thrust through the window
room was full of solid men in black uniforms
smashed it to pieces on the hearthstone
fragment of coral rolled across the mat
men hoisted her up by knees and shoulders

880-890.description: Winston observes changes in Mr. Charrington as he enters the room, revealing his true identity as a member of the Thought Police.
880-890.dialog_summary: Mr. Charrington orders a man to pick up the pieces of a shattered glass paperweight.
text_phrases: the clock on the mantelpiece said nine

880-890.scene_title: Winston in the Ministry of Love
880-890.description: Winston finds himself in a stark, high-ceilinged cell within the Ministry of Love, reflecting on his arrest and the conditions of his confinement.
880-890.location: Cell in the Ministry of Love
880-890.dialog_summary: A voice from the telescreen yells at Winston to keep his hands out of his pockets.
text_phrases: bench, or shelf, just wide enough to sit on

891-904.description: A tumultuous scene in a prison where various characters including a disruptive elderly woman are introduced. The woman is forcibly brought into the scene, interacts with Winston, and vomits on the floor.
891-904.dialog_summary: The elderly woman apologizes to Winston for sitting on him, explains her rough treatment by the guards, and vomits. She then strikes up a conversation with Winston, asking his name and commenting on the coincidence that they share the same surname.

891-904.description: Winston reflects on his physical pain, the uncertainty of time, and his surroundings in the prison cell. He contemplates his fate, the possibility of receiving a razor blade, and the unending torture he anticipates.
Ampleforth, a poet, is brought into Winston's cell. He appears disheveled and confused, wandering around the cell without noticing Winston.
text_phrases: steel door opened with a clang

905-933.description: Winston decides to speak to Ampleforth in their cell, discussing the reasons for their arrests and the peculiarities of language and poetry.
905-933.dialog_summary: Winston and Ampleforth discuss the reasons for their imprisonment and Ampleforth's mistake in his work. Ampleforth reflects on the limitations of the English language in poetry.
text_phrases: sat down awkwardly on the bench

905-933.description: Parsons enters the cell, startling Winston, and begins to confess and rationalize his arrest for thoughtcrime, expressing hope and fear about his fate.
905-933.dialog_summary: Parsons admits his guilt of thoughtcrime, expresses fear of being shot, and hopes for a lighter sentence due to his past loyalty to the Party. He reveals that his arrest was due to talking in his sleep.
text_phrases: wearing khaki shorts and a sports shirt
eyes had a wide-open, staring look

934-956.description: Parsons discusses how his daughter denounced him to the authorities, showing pride in her actions. He then uses the lavatory in the cell.
934-956.dialog_summary: Parsons tells Winston that his daughter reported him to the authorities. He expresses pride in her actions.

934-956.description: New prisoners are brought into the cell, including a woman who reacts with terror upon being sent to Room 101. A man with a skull-like face is also brought in, and another prisoner offers him bread, leading to a violent reaction from the guards.
934-956.dialog_summary: A woman is terrified of being sent to Room 101. A man offers bread to a starving prisoner, which results in punishment from the guards.

957-972.description: A man frantically tries to deflect attention from himself to another prisoner with a smashed face, as guards prepare to take him to Room 101.
957-972.dialog_summary: A man tries to convince the guards to take another prisoner instead of him, claiming the other prisoner spoke against the Party.
text_phrases: smashed face of the chinless man
iron legs that supported the bench
man's voice rose to a shriek

957-972.description: Winston experiences intense solitude and physical discomfort while reflecting on pain and his feelings for Julia.
text_phrases: dizzy to make sure of staying on his feet

957-972.description: O'Brien enters the room, surprising Winston, who momentarily forgets the presence of the telescreen.
957-972.dialog_summary: Winston expresses shock at seeing O'Brien arrested, but O'Brien reveals he has been on the Party's side all along.
text_phrases: broad-chested guard with a long black truncheon

974-983.description: Winston is subjected to physical and psychological torture by Party intellectuals and guards. He experiences constant slight pain, humiliation, and relentless questioning designed to break his spirit and force confessions.
974-983.dialog_summary: The interrogators alternate between abuse and appeals to Winston's loyalty to the Party, manipulating his emotions to extract confessions.
text_phrases: surly barber arriving to scrape his chin
men in white coats feeling his pulse
made him stand on one leg
shone glaring lights in his face

974-983.description: Winston hallucinates being in a corridor filled with light, laughing and confessing everything to an audience that already knows his history. This scene represents his mental breakdown and the complete control of the Party over his mind.
974-983.dialog_summary: Winston shouts out confessions while surrounded by familiar faces, all part of his hallucination.

974-983.description: In a moment of uncertainty, Winston hears O'Brien's voice, either in reality or in his mind, reassuring him that he has been under his protection and guidance for years, and promising salvation and perfection.
974-983.dialog_summary: O'Brien, either physically present or in Winston's mind, assures him of his ongoing protection and the pivotal moment of his salvation.
text_phrases: starting up from the plank bed

984-1004.description: Winston is immobilized and being interrogated by O'Brien in a stark, oppressive room. O'Brien manipulates a dial that controls the pain inflicted on Winston, using it as a tool for both torture and control during their conversation.
984-1004.dialog_summary: O'Brien warns Winston that he can inflict pain at any moment during their conversation. He questions Winston about the current war and past beliefs, using a dial to control the pain experienced by Winston as a means of control and intimidation.
text_phrases: the cell, or room, in which he now was
Under his hand there was a dial with a lever on top
a wave of pain flooded his body
O'Brien drew back the lever on the dial
An oblong slip of newspaper had appeared between O'Brien's fingers

1005-1047.description: Winston and O'Brien engage in a deep and intense conversation about the nature of reality, memory, and control. O'Brien manipulates Winston's perception of truth, using a dial to inflict pain when Winston disagrees with the Party's imposed reality.
1005-1047.dialog_summary: O'Brien questions Winston about the nature of reality and the past, emphasizing the Party's control over both. Winston struggles with the concept and the physical pain inflicted by O'Brien when he resists the Party's views.
text_phrases: O'Brien was looking down at him speculatively
His eyes flitted toward the dial
He laid his hand on the dial
O'Brien held up his left hand
The needle of the dial had shot up
The air tore into his lungs
The heavy, stern face and the four fingers filled his vision
Abruptly he was sitting up with O'Brien's arm round his shoulders

1048-1072.description: Winston is subjected to intense interrogation and torture by O'Brien, who is trying to force him to accept the Party's version of reality. The scene is intense, with physical and psychological pain inflicted on Winston to 'cure' him of his rebellious thoughts.
1048-1072.dialog_summary: O'Brien questions Winston about the number of fingers he sees, insisting on the Party's reality. He explains the purpose of the Ministry of Love is not to punish but to 'cure' and change people. O'Brien emphasizes that the Party alters people's beliefs to align with its own and that those who are brought here are never left uncured.
text_phrases: needle must be at seventy, seventy-five
O'Brien had drawn back the lever

1073-1085.description: O'Brien interrogates Winston, explaining the purpose of their methods and the inevitability of his conversion and destruction. The scene is intense, with O'Brien revealing the depth of the Party's control and manipulation.
1073-1085.dialog_summary: O'Brien explains to Winston why the Party interrogates and converts individuals before destroying them, emphasizing complete control over thoughts and loyalty. He asserts that resistance is futile and that Winston will be fundamentally changed.
text_phrases: heavy piece of apparatus being pushed into place
soft pads clamped themselves against Winston's temples
O'Brien laid a hand on his

1086-1126.description: Winston is being interrogated by O'Brien, who manipulates Winston's perception of reality and tries to reshape his memories and beliefs.
1086-1126.dialog_summary: O'Brien questions Winston about his memories and beliefs, manipulating his perception of reality. He discusses the nonexistence of a piece of paper, the constant state of war, and the existence of Big Brother. O'Brien also reveals Julia's betrayal and discusses the concept of nonexistence.
text_phrases: O'Brien held up the fingers of his left hand
man in the white coat break an ampoule and draw back the plunger of a syringe
O'Brien turned to Winston with a smile
Winston saw the man in the white coat

1127-1141.scene_title: Interrogation at the Ministry of Love
1127-1141.description: O'Brien interrogates Winston in a room at the Ministry of Love, discussing the nature of power and the purpose of the Party's rule. O'Brien reveals he co-authored Goldstein's book and dismisses the idea of a proletarian rebellion. The scene is intense, with O'Brien manipulating the pain dial to torture Winston as he questions him.
1127-1141.dialog_summary: O'Brien explains the true motive of the Party's quest for power, dismissing the contents of Goldstein's book and the possibility of a proletarian rebellion. He tortures Winston to suppress his thoughts of rebellion and asserts that the Party seeks power solely for its own sake.
text_phrases: pushed the lever of the dial up to thirty-five

1142-1159.description: O'Brien explains the concept of power to Winston, emphasizing the Party's control over reality and the mind.
1142-1159.dialog_summary: O'Brien discusses the nature of power, control over matter and mind, and the insignificance of external reality compared to the Party's doctrine. He dismisses the importance of physical laws and external entities like stars, asserting the Party's ability to redefine reality.
text_phrases: raise himself into a sitting position
silenced him by a movement of the hand

1160-1189.description: In a grim and tense scene, O'Brien describes a future dominated by the Party, filled with endless oppression and control, while Winston, though physically weak and mentally exhausted, tries to resist and argue against O'Brien's vision.
1160-1189.dialog_summary: O'Brien explains the perpetual and oppressive future planned by the Party, asserting control over all aspects of life and dismissing any possibility of rebellion or failure. Winston weakly objects, insisting that such a world is impossible and unsustainable, but O'Brien counters every argument, emphasizing the Party's absolute power and the irrelevance of individual dissent.
text_phrases: shrink back into the surface of the bed
three-sided mirror at the far end of the room

1190-1205.description: Winston observes his own reflection in a mirror, seeing the drastic changes and deterioration in his physical appearance.
1190-1205.dialog_summary: O'Brien confronts Winston about his physical and mental state, highlighting the severe changes and degradation. Winston insists he has not betrayed Julia.

1206-1214.description: The scene describes the protagonist's interaction with O'Brien, where he is told about his fate and his current state of recovery in the cell. The protagonist is growing healthier and is provided with basic amenities to make his stay more comfortable.
1206-1214.location: Cell in the Ministry of Love
1206-1214.dialog_summary: The protagonist asks O'Brien how soon he will be shot, and O'Brien responds that it might be a long time as he is a difficult case but assures him that everyone is cured sooner or later.
text_phrases: white light and the humming sound
pillow and a mattress on the plank bed
wash himself fairly frequently in a tin basin
new underclothes and a clean suit of overalls
dressed his varicose ulcer with soothing ointment
food was surprisingly good, with meat at every third meal
white slate with a stump of pencil tied to the corner

1215-1229.description: Winston sits and writes in his journal, grappling with the contradictions and indoctrinations of his society. He writes various paradoxical statements and reflects on the nature of reality and truth as dictated by the Party.
text_phrases: The pencil felt thick and awkward in his fingers.
He began to write down the thoughts that came into his head.

1215-1229.description: Winston experiences a moment of clarity and despair as he contemplates the inevitability of his situation and the omnipotent control of the Party over reality.
text_phrases: He set to work to exercise himself in crimestop.

1215-1229.description: Winston imagines walking in a sunlit passage, feeling a sense of peace and reconciliation with his fate, momentarily escaping the grim reality of his confinement.
1215-1229.dialog_summary: Winston cries out for Julia in a moment of intense emotional release, feeling her presence intensely.
text_phrases: He was walking down the corridor, waiting for the bullet.
He was in the Golden Country, following the foot track across the old rabbit-cropped pasture.

1230-1249.description: Winston lies on the bed, reflecting on his actions and the consequences of his outburst against the Party. He anticipates the arrival of the authorities due to his betrayal.
text_phrases: He lay back on the bed

1230-1249.description: O'Brien confronts Winston in his cell, discussing his thoughts and feelings towards Big Brother and instructing him on the emotional alignment he needs to achieve.
1230-1249.dialog_summary: O'Brien questions Winston about his feelings towards Big Brother and emphasizes the need for Winston to not only obey but also love Big Brother.

1230-1249.description: Winston is taken to Room 101, where he is strapped to a chair and faces his worst fear, as introduced by O'Brien.
1230-1249.dialog_summary: O'Brien explains to Winston that Room 101 contains the worst thing in the world, which everyone inherently knows.
text_phrases: He was strapped upright in a chair
A sort of pad gripped his head
The door opened and O'Brien came in
A guard came in, carrying something made of wire

1250-1265.description: O'Brien explains to Winston that the worst thing in the world varies from person to person, and for Winston, it is rats. He reveals a cage with rats divided into compartments, causing Winston to panic.
1250-1265.dialog_summary: O'Brien discusses various forms of death and reveals that Winston's greatest fear is rats. Winston reacts with panic and disbelief.
text_phrases: oblong wire cage with a handle on top
something that looked like a fencing mask
cage was divided lengthways into two compartments
some kind of creature in each
set it down carefully on the baize cloth

1250-1265.description: O'Brien manipulates the cage and explains how the rats could attack Winston, intensifying Winston's fear and desperation. Winston struggles physically and mentally as the cage comes closer.
1250-1265.dialog_summary: O'Brien describes the mechanics of the rat cage and how the rats will attack Winston. Winston struggles and contemplates a way to save himself.
text_phrases: mask will fit over your head
door of the cage will slide up
starving brutes will shoot out of it like bullets
They will leap onto your face and bore straight into it

1266-1277.description: Winston faces his greatest fear as a cage of rats is brought close to his face. In a moment of panic, he betrays Julia.
1266-1277.dialog_summary: O'Brien explains the use of rat torture, referencing Imperial China. Winston, in panic, begs O'Brien to do the torture to Julia instead of him.
text_phrases: The circle of the mask was large enough
The wire door was a couple of hand-spans from his face
One of them was leaping up and down
stood up, with his pink hands against the bars

1266-1277.description: Winston sits alone in the Chestnut Tree Cafe, drinking Victory Gin and reflecting on the war news and his life.
text_phrases: A ray of sunlight slanting through a window fell yellow on dusty tabletops
Winston sat in his usual corner, gazing into an empty glass
Unbidden, a waiter came and filled his glass up with Victory Gin
The chessboard was always waiting for him
He examined the chess problem and set out the pieces

1278-1289.description: A telescreen announces an important bulletin, urging everyone to pay attention at a specific time, hinting at bad news.
text_phrases: The tinkling music struck up again

1278-1289.description: Winston imagines the Eurasian army's movements and interacts with a chessboard, reflecting on strategic possibilities.
text_phrases: put the white knight back in its place

1278-1289.description: Winston encounters a changed woman in a cold, desolate park, leading to a brief and disheartening conversation.
1278-1289.dialog_summary: The woman admits to betraying Winston, and he acknowledges betraying her as well. She explains the desperation that leads to betrayal under threat.
text_phrases: sat down on two iron chairs

1290-1305.description: In a cold and windy setting, two characters have a conversation that leads to a decision to part ways. The male character follows the female for a while before deciding to head back to a warmer place, the Chestnut Tree Café.
1290-1305.location: Street leading to the Tube station
1290-1305.dialog_summary: The characters discuss their feelings after a significant event, agreeing that they must meet again, though the male character eventually decides to part ways.
text_phrases: The wind plastered their thin overalls against their bodies
She said something about catching her Tube and stood up to go
He followed irresolutely for a little distance
He was overwhelmed by a desire not so much to get away from Julia as to get back to the Chestnut Tree Café

1290-1305.description: The male character is at the Chestnut Tree Café, reminiscing and engaging in his daily routine of drinking gin, which dominates his existence.
1290-1305.dialog_summary: The male character reflects on his past and the routine of his life centered around gin and occasional work.
text_phrases: The tears welled up in his eyes
A passing waiter noticed that his glass was empty and came back with the gin bottle
He took up his glass and sniffed at it
It was gin that sank him into stupor every night, and gin that revived him every morning

1306-1311.description: The protagonist is distracted from his false memories by a chess game, but is startled by a sudden trumpet call.
text_phrases: pushed the picture out of his mind

1306-1311.description: A trumpet call announces a victory, causing excitement in the café and a flurry of reactions from Winston and the others present.
1306-1311.dialog_summary: Excited voice from the telescreen announces a victory and details of the battle.
text_phrases: excited voice was gabbling from the telescreen

1306-1311.description: Winston reflects on the news of victory and his past experiences, leading to a profound personal realization.
text_phrases: looked up again at the portrait of Big Brother
gin-scented tears trickled down the sides of his nose
